New Records: Ross Adair scored the third T20I century for Ireland, following in the footsteps of Kevin O'Brien and current captain Paul Stirling.
Key Match Events: Ireland opener Ross Adair and captain Paul Stirling's opening stand of 137 propelled Ireland to an impressive total of 195-6
Reeza Hendricks and Matthew Breetzke both made 51 to set up a victory platform at 157-3 for South Africa
Ireland's all-round performance was magnificent, while South Africa's was dismal
South Africa's batting decision-making in the closing stages of the run-chase was chaotic
Seamer Mark Adair was instrumental in the victory with 4-31 from his four overs
Right hander Adair received a chest-high full toss from Wiaan Mulder on 93 which he heaved over square leg for six
Rickelton’s quickfire 36 from 22 balls included a four and four sixes before he miscued a pull to square leg
Captain Aiden Markram (8) missed a reverse sweep against left arm spinner Humphreys and was bowled
Dashing footwork and quick hands brought Adair five fours and nine sixes
Stirling departed when an attempted upper-cut against Patrick Kruger landed in the gloves of ‘keeper Ryan Rickelton
George Dockrell finished unbeaten on 20 from 13 balls with just a single boundary
Williams (4-0-35-1) and Mulder (4-0-51-2) were far from their best while spinners Fortuin (2-0-24-0) and Nqaba Peter (2-0-29-0) suffered badly at the hands of the openers
Post-Match Reflections: Ireland's all-round performance was magnificent but South Africa’s was dismal
Ireland beat South Africa by 10-runs in the second T20I to level the series
Miscellaneous Highlights: South Africa comfortably won the first match at the same venue by eight-wickets chasing down Ireland’s 171-8 in just 17.4 overs
That record is now 6-1, with Ireland breaking South Africa's winning streak in T20Is
